data.label: analysis_parameters
data.description: dbt seed analysis_parameters

data.label: census_place_migration
data.description: Migration between census places for all years

data.label: census_place_population
data.description: Population of census places for all years

data.label: crosswalk_hist_id_to_hist_census_place_clean
data.description: Crosswalk between full count census hist_id and census place id for a given year (clean).

data.label: crosswalk_hist_id_to_hist_census_place_raw
data.description: Crosswalk between full count census hist_id and census place id for a given year (raw).

columns.name: histid
columns.description: Consistent historical data person identifier for the IPUMS full count data. This key is unique to each person-year combination. It can be used to match on one person years, but not to track individuals across years

columns.name: cpp_placeid
columns.description: The Census Place Project ID of the census place

data.label: ipums_full_count_census_place_id
data.description: IPUMS full count data with census place id for a given year.

data.label: ipums_full_count_census_place_id_all_years
data.description: IPUMS full count data with census place id for all years.

data.label: ipums_full_count_clean
data.description: IPUMS full count data for a given year (clean).

data.label: ipums_full_count_individual_migration
data.description: Individual migration data for all years. Using the census linking (hik) we track linked individual across years and observe if they have changed census place

columns.name: census_place_origin
columns.description: The Census Place Project ID of the census place where the person was living in the origin year

columns.name: census_place_destination
columns.description: The Census Place Project ID of the census place where the person was living in the destination year

data.label: ipums_full_count_raw
data.description: IPUMS full count data for a given year (raw).

columns.name: histid
columns.description: Consistent historical data person identifier for the IPUMS full count data. This key is unique to each person-year combination. It can be used to match on one person years, but not to track individuals across years

columns.name: hik
columns.description: Historical identification key for the IPUMS full count data. This key is unique to each person. It can be used to match people across years. It is computed via the linking procedure.

data.label: ipums_usa_full_count_downloaded
data.description: IPUMS USA Full Count data 1850-1940.

data.label: nhgis_place_geom_1900_2010_downloaded
data.description: NHGIS Place Geometry 1900-2010.

data.label: nhgis_place_population_1990_2020_downloaded
data.description: NHGIS Place Population 1990-2020.

data.label: raw_data_zenodo
data.description: A zip file called raw_data.zip containing all the raw data used in the project that are redistributable. See readme/README_RAW_DATA.md for more details.

data.label: usa_average_growth
data.description: The average growth of the population of the cities over one decade. This average growth is weighted by the population of the cities.

columns.name: log_average_growth
columns.description: The log10 average growth of the population of the cities over one decade. This average growth is weighted by the population of the cities.

data.label: usa_census_place_stable_geom
data.description: Geometry of census place stable

data.label: usa_census_place_stable_population
data.description: Population of census place stable. Union of the normalized population before 1940 and the NHGIS population from 1990 to 2020.

data.label: usa_census_place_stable_population_interpolated
data.description: Population of census place stable interpolated where is missing or anomalous. The population is interpolated using the closest population observations.

columns.name: population_interpolated
columns.description: A flag indicating if the population is interpolated or not. 1 if the population is interpolated, 0 otherwise

data.label: usa_census_place_stable_population_with_anomaly_flags
data.description: Population of census place stable with anomaly flags. The anomaly flags are set to 1 if the population is anomalous. Anomalous population is defined as a population that grows fast in one year and shrinks fast in the next year, creating a spike or a dip.

columns.name: anomaly_flag
columns.description: 1 if the population is anomalous, 0 otherwise

data.label: usa_cluster_base_geom
data.description: The geometry of the base clusters. These clusters are created from the raster census place. We use DBSCAN to cluster the urban pixels and then we union the pixels to get the cluster geometry.

columns.name: cluster_id
columns.description: The ID of the cluster. This is a concatenation of the year, pixel_threshold, and an integer. This integer is used to assign a unique deterministic cluster_id to each cluster_base. It is obtained by ordering the centroids of clusters from west to east and then from north to south.

columns.name: urban_threshold
columns.description: The urban pixel threshold used to classify the pixels as urban or not

columns.name: geom
columns.description: The geometry of the cluster in Coordinate reference system = EPSG:5070

data.label: usa_cluster_base_matching
data.description: Matching between cluster geometries across different years. We take pairs of years and match clusters that intersect with each other spatially. Clusters that do not intersect with each other are matched to themselves. This yields a bipartite graph.

columns.name: left_cluster_id
columns.description: The cluster ID of one endpoint of the edge

columns.name: right_cluster_id
columns.description: The cluster ID of the other endpoint of the edge

columns.name: y1
columns.description: The startpoint of the cluster growth

columns.name: y2
columns.description: The endpoint of the cluster growth

columns.name: urban_threshold
columns.description: The urban pixel threshold used to classify the pixels as urban or not

data.label: usa_cluster_growth_geom
data.description: The geometry of the cluster growth. A cluster growth is a connected component in the bipartite graph matching across years. It is used to assign stable boundaries to a cluster across years to compute the population growth. These stable boundaries are computed as the spatial union of the clusters in the connected component.

columns.name: cluster_id
columns.description: The ID of the cluster growth. This is a concatenation of y1, y2 (the years for which the cluster growth is computed), pixel_threshold, and an integer. This integer is used to assign a unique deterministic cluster_id to each cluster_growth. It is obtained by ordering the centroids of clusters from west to east and then from north to south.

columns.name: y1
columns.description: The startpoint of the cluster growth

columns.name: y2
columns.description: The endpoint of the cluster growth

columns.name: geom
columns.description: The geometry of the cluster in Coordinate reference system = EPSG:5070

data.label: usa_cluster_growth_population
data.description: The population of the cluster growth at the startpoint (y1) and endpoint (y2). The population of the cluster in year y1 is computed as the sum of the population of the census places in year y1 that are contained within that cluster growth. Same for the population in year y2.

columns.name: population_y1
columns.description: The population of the cluster growth at the startpoint

columns.name: population_y2
columns.description: The population of the cluster growth at the endpoint

data.label: usa_cluster_growth_population_analysis
data.description: For our final analysis, we build different analysis datasets based on the specs in analysis parameters. These datasets are essentially refined version of our based dataset usa_cluster_growth_population under different analysis parameters, like the urban threshold, the city population threshold. This tables joins all these datasets together and indexes them by analysis_id.

data.label: usa_crosswalk_component_id_to_cluster_id
data.description: Crosswalk mapping each cluster to its connected component in the bipartite graph matching across years. Each connected component correpsonds to a unique cluster growth.

columns.name: component_id
columns.description: The ID of the connected component

data.label: usa_crosswalk_hist_census_place_to_nhgis_census_place
data.description: Crosswalk between historical census places and NHGIS census places. Each historical census place is linked to its closest NHGIS census place.

columns.name: distance
columns.description: The distance between the historical census place and the NHGIS census place

data.label: usa_crosswalk_nhgis_census_place_to_census_place_stable
data.description: Crosswalk from NHGIS census place to census place stable. The ID of the census place stable is the NHGIS ID of the most populous census place in the connected component of the equivalence network. This makes the crosswalk deterministit.

columns.name: census_place_stable_id
columns.description: The NHGISPLACE code of the stable census place (connected component of the equivalence network)

data.label: usa_crosswalk_nhgis_census_place_to_connected_component
data.description: Crosswalk from NHGIS census place to connected component of network of equivalent census places

columns.name: component_id
columns.description: The ID of the connected component

data.label: usa_dataset_summary_table
data.description: A summary table of the USA dataset used for the analysis.

columns.name: num_cities
columns.description: The number of cities in the dataset

columns.name: num_years
columns.description: The number of years in the dataset

columns.name: min_year
columns.description: The earliest year in the dataset

columns.name: max_year
columns.description: The latest year in the dataset

data.label: usa_hist_census_place_geom
data.description: The geometry of historical census places from the Census Place Project

columns.name: geom
columns.description: The geometry of the census place in EPSG:5070

data.label: usa_hist_census_place_geom_raw
data.description: Geometry of historical census places from the Census Place Project

columns.name: lon
columns.description: The longitude of the census place

columns.name: lat
columns.description: The latitude of the census place

data.label: usa_hist_census_place_migration
data.description: Migration between historical census places from the Census Place Project. Same as the census_place_migration asset in the ipums_full_count defs.

data.label: usa_hist_census_place_population
data.description: Population of historical census places from the Census Place Project. Same as the census_place_population asset in the ipums_full_count defs.

data.label: usa_nhgis_census_place_appearances
data.description: Number of times a census place appears in the data and the last year it appears in the data

columns.name: num_appearances
columns.description: The number of times the census place appears in the data

columns.name: last_appearance
columns.description: The last year the census place appears in the data

data.label: usa_nhgis_census_place_equivalence_network
data.description: Equivalence network between NHGIS census places. The edges of this network are decided based on the following rules: 1. If a census place disappears from the data, we select a 'continuation' place and link it to the census place that disappeared. This continuation place is: (a) the census place that has the highest migration probability to the disappearing place in the year of disappearance; (b) the census place that is the nearest neighbor of the disappearing place. 2. If two census places have a high migration probability, we link them. The migration probability is considered high if it is higher than 0.t and the distance between the places is less than 30000 meters. 3. We link census place to themselves (because a place is always equivalent to itself).

columns.name: left_census_place_id
columns.description: The NHGISPLACE code of one endpoint of the edge

columns.name: right_census_place_id
columns.description: The NHGISPLACE code of the other endpoint of the edge

data.label: usa_nhgis_census_place_geom
data.description: The geometry of census places from NHGIS

columns.name: census_place_id
columns.description: The NHGISPLACE code, a consistent identifier across time for place points.

columns.name: census_place_name
columns.description: The name of the census place

columns.name: geom
columns.description: The geometry of the census place in EPSG:5070

data.label: usa_nhgis_census_place_geom_all_years_raw
data.description: Geometry of NHGIS census places between 1900 and 2010

columns.name: NHGISPLACE
columns.description: The NHGIS ID of the census place

columns.name: PLACE
columns.description: The name of the census place

columns.name: geometry
columns.description: The geometry of the census place (an point)

data.label: usa_nhgis_census_place_linked_population
data.description: Linked population of NHGIS census places aggregated from hist census place migration. It is important to note that census place population and linked population are different because not all individuals are linked. To compute migration probabilities, we need to use the linked population, because migrants are part of the linked population.

columns.name: population
columns.description: The linked population of the census place. Sum of all migrants that were there in the origin year.

data.label: usa_nhgis_census_place_migration
data.description: Migration flows between NHGIS census places aggregated from hist census place migration

data.label: usa_nhgis_census_place_migration_probability
data.description: Migration probability between two census places. It is the ratio of the number of migrants to the linked population of the origin census place.

columns.name: census_place_origin
columns.description: The NHGISPLACE code of the census place where the person was living in the origin year

columns.name: census_place_destination
columns.description: The NHGISPLACE code of the census place where the person was living in the destination year

data.label: usa_nhgis_census_place_nearest_neighbors
data.description: Nearest neighbors for each NHGIS census place. We use the nearest neighbors as a fallback for places that disappear from the data and for which we have no migration information.

columns.name: neighbor_census_place_id
columns.description: The NHGISPLACE code of the nearest neighbor

columns.name: distance
columns.description: The distance between the census place and the nearest neighbor

data.label: usa_nhgis_census_place_population
data.description: Population of NHGIS census places aggregated from hist census place population

data.label: usa_nhgis_census_place_population_1990_2020
data.description: The time series ofpopulation of census places from NHGIS

data.label: usa_nhgis_census_place_population_1990_2020_raw
data.description: Population of NHGIS census places between 1990 and 2020

columns.name: GISJOIN
columns.description: Standard identifiers to join with boundary files

data.label: usa_rank_size_slopes
data.description: We take the log-rank and log-size of the cities in a given year and fit a curve through it using a penalized B-spline. We then compute the average slope of the curve.

columns.name: rank_size_slope
columns.description: The average slope of the log-rank vs log-size curve fitted using a penalized B-spline

data.label: usa_rank_size_slopes_change
data.description: The change in the rank-size slope from some base year to a given year.

columns.name: year_base
columns.description: The base year from which the change is computed

columns.name: rank_size_slope_change
columns.description: The change in the rank-size slope from the base year to the given year.

data.label: usa_rank_vs_size
data.description: The log-rank of the cities  (1 = largest city), vs their log-population in a given decade.

columns.name: log_population
columns.description: The log10 of the population of the city

columns.name: log_rank
columns.description: The log10 of the rank of the city

data.label: usa_raster_census_place
data.description: A raster with the population of the census place stable for each year. We take the template raster and fill it with values. Each raster cell in a given year is given as value the sum of the population in the census place stable contained within that cell in that year.

columns.name: rast
columns.description: The raster tiles (each tile contains many cells). Coordinate reference system = EPSG:5070

data.label: usa_raster_census_place_convolved_all_years
data.description: The union of all the convolved raster tables into a single table

data.label: usa_raster_census_place_convolved_year
data.description: Convolution of the raster census place for a given year. We apply a 2D exponential kernel to the raster to smooth the population values. The original raster is very spiky because census place population are assigned to the cells contained within the census place. The convolution kernel spreads out the population around the cells containing the x, y coordinates of the census place.

columns.name: rast
columns.description: The raster. Its just one big tile with all the cells.

data.label: usa_size_vs_growth
data.description: The log population of cities at the start of a decade and the log growth of the city over the decade

columns.name: log_population
columns.description: The log10 population of the city at the start of the decade

columns.name: log_growth
columns.description: The log10 growth of the city over the decade

data.label: usa_size_vs_growth_normalized
data.description: The normalized log growth of the city over the decade. The normalized log growth is the log growth minus the average growth of the population nationwide.

columns.name: normalized_log_growth
columns.description: The normalized log growth of the city over the decade computed as the log growth minus the average growth of the population nationwide

data.label: usa_states_geom
data.description: The geometry of the states of the USA

columns.name: state_code

columns.name: state_name
columns.description: The name of the state (e.g. California, New York)

columns.name: geom
columns.description: The geometry of the state in EPSG:5070

data.label: usa_states_geom_raw
data.description: Geometry of the states of the USA

columns.name: State_Code
columns.description: The two letter code of the state (e.g. CA, NY)

columns.name: State_Name
columns.description: The name of the state (e.g. California, New York)

data.label: usa_template_raster
data.description: A template raster covering the continental USA. The raster is a box that covers all US states except Alaska and Hawaii.

data.label: usa_year_epoch
data.description: We group years into three epochs: 1850-1880, 1900-1940, 1990-2020.

data.label: world_average_growth
data.description: The log10 average growth of the population of the cities within countries over one decade. This average growth is weighted by the population of the cities.

columns.name: year
columns.description: The start year of the decade.

columns.name: log_average_growth
columns.description: The log10 of the average growth of the population of the country across years

data.label: world_average_size_growth_slope_with_borders
data.description: The average size growth slope of the countries across the period of observation, with borders. This is used to plot a map of the world with the average size growth slope by countries.

columns.name: size_growth_slope
columns.description: The average value of the size-growth slope across the observation period (see world_size_growth_slopes_historical for a definition of size-growth slope)

columns.name: geom
columns.description: The geometry of the country borders in 2019 in the Mollweide projection (EPSG:54009)

data.label: world_cluster_base_geom
data.description: The geometry of the base clusters. These clusters are created from the GHSL degree of urbanization raster. We use DBSCAN to cluster the urban pixels and then we union the pixels to get the cluster geometry.

columns.name: cluster_id
columns.description: The ID of the cluster. This is a concatenation of the year, pixel_threshold, and an integer. This integer is used to assign a unique deterministic cluster_id to each cluster_base. It is obtained by ordering the centroids of clusters from west to east and then from north to south.

columns.name: urban_threshold
columns.description: The degree-of-urbanization threshold used to classify the pixels as urban or not. Note that this threshol is exlcusive, meaning that a threshold at 21 means that pixels strictly greater than 21 are urban and pixels less than or equal to 21 are not urban.

columns.name: geom
columns.description: The geometry of the cluster in Coordinate reference system = EPSG:54009

data.label: world_cluster_base_matching
data.description: Matching between cluster geometries across different years. We take pairs of years and match clusters that intersect with each other spatially. Clusters that do not intersect with each other are matched to themselves. This yields a bipartite graph.

columns.name: left_cluster_id
columns.description: The cluster ID of one endpoint of the edge

columns.name: right_cluster_id
columns.description: The cluster ID of the other endpoint of the edge

columns.name: y1
columns.description: The startpoint of the cluster growth

columns.name: y2
columns.description: The endpoint of the cluster growth

data.label: world_cluster_growth_geocoding
data.description: The geocoding of the cluster growth. We assign a country to each cluster growth. Clusters that intersect with multiple countries are assigned to both countries.

columns.name: n_matched_countries
columns.description: The number of countries that the cluster growth intersects with

data.label: world_cluster_growth_geom
data.description: The geometry of the cluster growth. A cluster growth is a connected component in the bipartite graph matching across years. It is used to assign stable boundaries to a cluster across years to compute the population growth. These stable boundaries are computed as the spatial union of the clusters in the connected component.

columns.name: cluster_id
columns.description: The ID of the cluster growth. This is a concatenation of y1, y2 (the years for which the cluster growth is computed), pixel_threshold, and an integer. This integer is used to assign a unique deterministic cluster_id to each cluster_growth. It is obtained by ordering the centroids of clusters from west to east and then from north to south.

columns.name: y1
columns.description: The startpoint of the cluster growth

columns.name: y2
columns.description: The endpoint of the cluster growth

columns.name: geom
columns.description: The geometry of the cluster in Coordinate reference system = EPSG:54009

data.label: world_cluster_growth_population
data.description: The population of the cluster growth at the startpoint (y1) and endpoint (y2). The population of the cluster in year y1 is computed as the sum of the population of all pixels in the GHSL population raster that intersect with the cluster growth in year y1. Same for the population in year y2.

columns.name: population_y1
columns.description: The population of the cluster growth at the startpoint (y1)

columns.name: population_y2
columns.description: The population of the cluster growth at the endpoint (y2)

data.label: world_cluster_growth_population_country
data.description: Cluster growth population joined with country codes from world bank

data.label: world_cluster_growth_population_country_analysis
data.description: For our final analysis, we build different analysis datasets based on the specs in analysis parameters. These datasets are essentially refined version of our based dataset world_cluster_growth_population_country under different analysis parameters, like the urban threshold, the city population threshold, the country min number of cities, and the countries to exclude. This tables joins all these datasets together and indexes them by analysis_id.

data.label: world_linearity_test_rank_vs_size
data.description: We measure the distortion of the log-rank vs log-size by computing the maximum residual from the line fit through an OLS regression. Large residuals indicate non-linearity.

columns.name: year
columns.description: The start year of the decade

columns.name: max_resid
columns.description: The maximum residual from the line fit through an OLS regression

data.label: world_linearity_test_size_vs_growth
data.description: We test the linearity of the log-size vs log-growth curve using a bootstrap test. We do this only for the main analysis id because it takes too long to run for all analysis ids.

columns.name: year
columns.description: The start year of the decade

columns.name: reject_linear
columns.description: Whether the null hypothesis of linearity is rejected using a threshold of 0.05

data.label: world_paper_stats
data.description: A table of statistics used in the paper.

columns.name: description
columns.description: The description of the statistic computed

columns.name: value
columns.description: The value of the statistic computed

data.label: world_population
data.description: The population of the world with future projections until 2100 from Our World in Data

columns.name: country
columns.description: The world bank code of the country

columns.name: projection
columns.description: Whether the population is a projection or not

data.label: world_population_raw
data.description: Population data with future projections from Our World in Data

columns.name: Code
columns.description: The world bank code of the country

columns.name: Population (historical)
columns.description: The historical population of the country before 2024 (excl. 2024)

columns.name: Population (projections)
columns.description: The projected population of the country after 2024 (incl. 2024)

data.label: world_population_share_cities_above_1m
data.description: The union of the historical and projected data. Historical data is before 2025 (2025 included), and projections are after 2025 (2025 excluded).

columns.name: urban_population_share_cities_above_one_million
columns.description: The urban population share of cities above 1 million

data.label: world_population_share_cities_above_1m_historical
data.description: The urban (note urban not total!) population share of cities above 1 million. This is computed from the population data by summing the total population and that of cities above 1 million.

columns.name: urban_population_share_cities_above_one_million
columns.description: The urban population share of cities above 1 million

data.label: world_population_share_cities_above_1m_projections
data.description: The urban population share of cities above 1 million projected into the future. The projections are based on a simple equation relating the shares to the rank-size slopes: s = (x_max^{1-alpha} - z^{1-alpha}) / (x_max^{1-alpha} - x_min^{1-alpha}) where x_max, x_min are upper and lower bounds of the urban population, z is 1 million, and alpha is the zipf exponent (1 / rank_size_slope). To compute these projections we set x_min = 5000, z = 1 million, and alpha = 1 / rank_size_slope. We set x_max = omega * urban_population, where omega is a free parameter. We tune omega in the marcro get_optimal_omegas_population_share_cities_above_1m_projections.

columns.name: urban_population_share_cities_above_one_million
columns.description: The urban population share of cities above 1 million projected with the above method.

data.label: world_population_share_cities_above_1m_projections_ols
data.description: The population share of cities with a population above 1 million calculated using our projection method. This is estimated in the same way as world_population_share_cities_above_1m_projections (i.e., with the equation s = (x_max^{1-alpha} - z^{1-alpha}) / (x_max^{1-alpha} - x_min^{1-alpha})). However, this table uses OLS estimates of the rank-size slope rather than spline based ones. We do not calculate future values of the rank size slope because the main focus here is to compare whether spline based or OLS based estimates are better at reproducing historical data.

columns.name: population_share_cities_above_1m
columns.description: The population share of cities with a population above 1 million projected using the method described in world_population_share_cities_above_1m_projections, but using OLS estimates of the rank-size slope rather than spline based ones.

data.label: world_rank_size_slopes
data.description: The union of rank-size slopes from historical data and projections.

columns.name: is_projection
columns.description: Whether the rank-size slope is a projection or not

data.label: world_rank_size_slopes_change
data.description: The change in the rank-size slope between a base year and a given year.

columns.name: year_base
columns.description: The base year from which we measure the change in the rank-size slope

columns.name: rank_size_slope_change
columns.description: The change in the rank-size slope between the base year and the given year

data.label: world_rank_size_slopes_change_1975_2025
data.description: The change in the rank-size slope between 1975 and 2025, with base year 1975.

columns.name: rank_size_slope_change
columns.description: The change in the rank-size slope between 1975 and 2025 with base year 1975

data.label: world_rank_size_slopes_change_2025_2075
data.description: The projected change in the rank-size slope between 2025 and 2075, with base year 2025.

columns.name: rank_size_slope_change
columns.description: The change in the rank-size slope between 2025 and 2075 with base year 2025

data.label: world_rank_size_slopes_decade_change
data.description: The change in the rank-size slope between a decade and the next decade.

columns.name: year
columns.description: This start year of the decade

columns.name: rank_size_slope_decade_change
columns.description: The change in the rank-size slope between the start end end of the decade

data.label: world_rank_size_slopes_historical
data.description: We take city log-rank (1=largest city) and log-size in a given year for various countries and years. We then fit a curve through it using a penalized B-spline and compute the average slope of the curve.

columns.name: rank_size_slope
columns.description: The average slope of the log-rank vs log-size curve fitted using a penalized B-spline

data.label: world_rank_size_slopes_historical_ols
data.description: We take the city log-rank and log-size in a given year for various countries and years. We then fit an OLS regression (instead of a penalized B-spline) and take the slope coefficient.

columns.name: year
columns.description: The start year of the decade

columns.name: rank_size_slope
columns.description: The coefficient of and OLS regression of log-rank vs log-size

data.label: world_rank_size_slopes_ols_decade_change
data.description: The change in the rank-size slope (estimated with OLS) over one decade. This table is to compare spline based esitimates of the rank-size slope to OLS estimate in the Supplementary Information.

columns.name: rank_size_slope_decade_change
columns.description: The change in the rank-size slope (estimated with OLS) from the start of the decade to the end of the decade

data.label: world_rank_size_slopes_projections
data.description: The slopes of the log-rank vs log-size projected forward in time. The projection are based on an equation relating rank-size slopes and size-growth slopes: a_{t+10} = a_t * (1 + b_{t}) where a_t is the rank-size slope in year t and b_t is the size growth slope in year t.

columns.name: rank_size_slope
columns.description: The average slope of the log-rank vs log-size curve calculated with out projection method

data.label: world_rank_vs_size
data.description: The log-rank of the cities  (1 = largest city), vs their log-population in a given decade.

columns.name: log_population
columns.description: The log10 of the population of the city

columns.name: log_rank
columns.description: The log10 of the rank of the city

data.label: world_raster_ghsl_pop
data.description: The population raster from GHSL

columns.name: rid
columns.description: The id of the raster tile

columns.name: rast
columns.description: The raster tiles in CRS = Mollweide (EPSG:54009)

data.label: world_raster_ghsl_pop_all_years
data.description: The union of all population raster tables into one table

columns.name: rast
columns.description: The raster tiles in CRS = Mollweide (EPSG:54009)

data.label: world_raster_ghsl_smod
data.description: The degree of urbanization raster from the GHSL

columns.name: rid
columns.description: The id of the raster tile

columns.name: rast
columns.description: The raster tiles in CRS = Mollweide (EPSG:54009)

data.label: world_raster_ghsl_smod_all_years
data.description: The union of all degree of urbanization raster tables into one table

columns.name: rast
columns.description: The raster tiles in CRS = Mollweide (EPSG:54009)

data.label: world_region_regression_with_urbanization_controls
data.description: We regress regional dummies against the size growth slopes of countries, with and without controls for the urban population share. We then save the coefficients and confidence intervals for the regional dummies of each region.

columns.name: coeff_no_control
columns.description: The coefficient of the region without urbanization controls

columns.name: coeff_with_control
columns.description: The coefficient of the region with urbanization controls

columns.name: ci_low_no_control
columns.description: The lower confidence interval of the coefficient of the region without urbanization controls

columns.name: ci_high_no_control
columns.description: The upper confidence interval of the coefficient of the region without urbanization controls

columns.name: ci_low_with_control
columns.description: The lower confidence interval of the coefficient of the region with urbanization controls

columns.name: ci_high_with_control
columns.description: The upper confidence interval of the coefficient of the region with urbanization controls

data.label: world_size_growth_slopes_historical
data.description: We take city log-size at the start of a decade and log-growth over that decade for various countries and years. We then fit a curve through it using a penalized B-spline and compute the average slope of the curve.

columns.name: year
columns.description: The start year of the decade

columns.name: size_growth_slope
columns.description: The average slope of the log-size vs log-growth curve fitted using a penalized B-spline

data.label: world_size_growth_slopes_historical_ols
data.description: We take city log-size at the start of the decade against their log-growth over one decade for various countries and years. We then fit an OLS regression (instead of a penalized B-spline) and take the slope coefficient.

columns.name: year
columns.description: The start year of the decade

columns.name: size_growth_slope
columns.description: The coefficient of and OLS regression of log-size vs log-growth

data.label: world_size_growth_slopes_historical_urbanization
data.description: The slopes of the log-size vs log-growth curve on historical data, with urban population share data.

data.label: world_size_growth_slopes_projections
data.description: Projections for the size growth slopes based on the urban population share. Given the relationship between the size growth slope and the urban population share from historical data, we project the size growth slope forward in time using projections of the urban population share.

columns.name: size_growth_slope
columns.description: The projection of the size growth slope based on the urban population share.

data.label: world_size_vs_growth
data.description: The log-size of cluster at the start of a decade and the log-growth of the clusters over a decade.

columns.name: year
columns.description: The start year of the decade.

columns.name: log_population
columns.description: The log10 of the population of the cluster growth at the start of the decade

columns.name: log_growth
columns.description: The log10 of the growth of the population growth of the cluster between the start of the decade and the end of the decade

data.label: world_size_vs_growth_normalized
data.description: We normalize the growth of the population of the clusters by the average growth of the population of the country.

columns.name: normalized_log_growth
columns.description: The log10 of the growth of the population of the cluster growth at the start of the decade, normalized by the average growth of the population of the country

data.label: world_size_vs_growth_normalized_by_group
data.description: We take the world_size_vs_growth_normalized table and we add a column to indicate the group of the city: 'above_1m', 'below_1m', or 'largest_city'. The 'largest_city' group is the city with the largest population in the country in the given year. We also exponentiate the population and growth columns to get the actual population and growth, so we can compute weighted average of growth by city population. Note that the groups are not mutually exclusive, so some cities may belong to multiple groups.

columns.name: city_group
columns.description: The group of the city: 'above_1m', 'below_1m', or 'largest_city'

data.label: world_urban_population
data.description: The urban population of countries around the world (with projections to 2100). This obtained by multipling the population of the country by the urban population share of the country.

columns.name: country
columns.description: World bank code of the country

columns.name: urban_population
columns.description: The urban population of the country

data.label: world_urbanization
data.description: see world_urbanization_raw

data.label: world_urbanization_groups
data.description: The urban population share groups of the countries. There are two groups: 0-60% and 60-100% based on the urban population share of the country in 1975.

columns.name: country
columns.description: The country code from world bank

columns.name: urban_population_share_group
columns.description: The urban population share group of the country: '0-60%' or '60-100%'

data.label: world_urbanization_raw
data.description: Urbanization data with future projections from https://doi.org/10.6084/m9.figshare.c.5521821

columns.name: country
columns.description: The world bank code of the country

columns.name: urban_population_share
columns.description: The urban population share of the country
